abstract.text: A container for a set of items that lays out the items along a path.

inlineContent.text: Groups determine how the items in a collection view lay out in relation to each other. A group might lay out its items in a horizontal row, a vertical column, or a custom arrangement. A group determines the rules for how items are rendered in relation to each other, but in itself doesn’t render any content.
For example, in the Photos app, a group of items is a row of photos. In the App Store app, a group might be a single column of cells (items) arranged in a vertical column.

Each group specifies its own size in terms of a width dimension and a height dimension. Groups can express their dimensions relative to their container, as an absolute value, or as an estimated value that might change at runtime, like in response to a change in system font size. For more information, see
Because a group is a subclass of
, it behaves like an item. You can combine a group with other items and groups into more complex layouts.
After you configure a group, you must initialize a section (
) of your collection view layout with that group.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An individual dimension representing an item’s width or height in a collection view.
A container for a set of items that lays out the items along a path.
Creates a group of the specified size, with an item provider that creates a custom arrangement for those items.
Creates a group of the specified size, containing an array of equally sized items arranged in a horizontal line up to the number specified by count.
Creates a group of the specified size, containing an array of items arranged in a horizontal line.
The amount of space between the items in the group.
An array of the items contained in the group.
An array of the supplementary items that are anchored to the group.
Creates a group of the specified size, containing an array of equally sized items arranged in a vertical line up to the number specified by count.
Creates a group of the specified size, containing an array of items arranged in a vertical line.
Returns a string with an ASCII representation of the group.
The most basic component of a collection view’s layout.
A container that combines a set of groups into distinct visual groupings.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.

media-3568663.alt: Schematic representation of the App Store app on iOS, showing a collection view with a compositional layout. The layout is composed of horizontally-scrolling sections that have different layouts. The top section shows one group with one item visible onscreen, with other groups peeking in from the sides of the screen. The bottom section shows one group that’s a column of three cells, each of those cells being an item. The two different types of groups are highlighted and labeled as groups.

media-3568666.alt: Illustration of group nesting in a compositional layout. A larger group contains one large item on the leading side and two smaller items stacked vertically in a nested group on the trailing side.
